content.description:
Climb up an easy wide crack, and end up in a chimney-like feature. Sweet and varied.

just right of Fanfare for the Common Man
SR

Quite easy for the first half, maybe 5.4. Climb up a selection of cracks and features to a small alcove, pull a jug and then you're into the real climbing.  
  
 The thin seam at the top provides some thoughtful moments for the 5.9 leader. Gear is solid though, takes great nuts. The face is featured enough to keep the grade down.

On the (climber's) left section of the crag. You'll probably notice two thin seams on the upper part of the crag. One is above two bolts (It's Not Easy Being Green), the other is to the left of that one. Climb under the one to the left.
Anything you want for the bottom section, small stuff (wires, cams as small as blue metolius...maybe you could place smaller if you wanted). Chains at the top.

Leftmost crack on wall.  Shorter yet still has a short crux.

left most route
SR.  bolted anchor.

Start under a small roof with a very positive left jug above it. Lock off, pull up and start into the seam. The gear in the thin is thinner than it looks from the ground, I didn't find a place for anything as big as a yellow Metolius until higher up. Small wires, small cams. Distinct crux mid-height as you're passing a horizontal break with your feet. It's steeper and the locks are pretty thin. Like the rest of the crag, there are lots of rests everywhere including immediately before and after the crux. The only route that starts below the head-height roof on the lower part of the crag. The thin seam is fairly distinctive. Small gear from purple Metolius/green C3 to #1 Camalot. Doubles in tips/fingers pieces. Chains at the top.

Takes good small gear. I fiddled with small wires my first time up this, but climbed it again last weekend and didn't waste my time with any nuts, took solid cams at comforting intervals.

A fun route that tackles bouldery moves in a dihedral down low to cruisey fingers and hands with lots of good rests above. Decidedly not sustained. Protection is good but you can't place it whenever you want to. Starts on the right of a large rectangular bay ("pop-sickle" takes the left side).

Protects well with small cams and nuts, plus a 1-2" cam or nut for the top. The crux takes small gear (I used a 0 mastercam). Bolts and chains up top.

The crag's sole mixed route, start up a fun finger crack to the very restful alcove then move onto the face above. Pass two bolts on thin, cruxy moves, punch it through 20 more feet with decent, but spacey protection to a short and very fun horizontal crack to top out.

look for the bolts. Below them is a big, square, alcove. Start at the base of the crack which leads to the left side of the alcove
standard rack to 3" (only one large placement at the top) and two bolts. The first bolt can be clipped from a comfortable position if you're tall, shorter climbers will need to move into more insecure terrain to reach it. There are few placements possible between the bolts and the upper horizontal crack and I didn't find them particularly confidence-inspiring.

A fairly straight-forward climb with lots of small ledges and no-hands rests. An interesting mantle at before the anchors gives the route its grade.

The route is just to the left of the roof at the beginning of Groovy Guru. Begin up a wider crack, then up broken cracks in a roughly vertical manner.
Protects well with a single rack and some nuts. Chain anchor.

Start in the right facing corner next to Hungry, Hungry Hippos climb to the end of the crack system, move right on edges and than back again to crack/edges. Crux is at the thin crack at the top. The crux can be bypassed using Rick’s Root on the left (10a).

Start in the right facing corner next to Hungry, Hungry Hippos in the large rectangular hole.
SR to #1. Chains on top.

Climb the crack system past a small tree stump and through the right side of a large square hole, finish on nice finger/hand crack.

Located to the right of It’s Not Easy Being Green. Rappel or walk off
SR to #2, chains on top

An uninspiring squeeze-job between Groovy Guru and Smells Like Chicken. Shares an anchor with the latter and shares holds with both. 
  
 Start in a weird alcove, rise above and make some finger moves, you'll be done before you know it.

Mostly finger-sized gear, standard rack will see you through. Chains at the top, but like most routes at the crag the chains are slightly offset to make it difficult to equalize an anchor with two draws.

Starts with a friendly jug-haul through an unprotected dihedral for a few moves. Good hands, good feet. Then up a hand-fist crack for a few moves, again with good feet. Pull up and stand, then traverse right to the anchor.  
  
 The FAists called it 5.8, but I'm not sure where the 5.8 part is.

Starts with a small ramp to a right-facing dihedral, just to the right of Tastes Like Chicken.
I placed two .75s and a #3 Camalot. I'm sure you could switch it up. Chains at the top.

Like many of the routes in this area "tastes like chicken" follows a series of discontinuous cracks separated by restful ledges. Starts with a few cruxy moves into a wide hands crack, a quick rest, then a burly-looking offwidth for 15 feet (easier than it looks, the crack is highly featured). Finishes on perfect hands. Could be great preactice for wide technique if you ignore the features in the crack.

on the far right side of the crag, look for the wide crack about 15 feet up.
gear .5-5" (a #4 camalot is perfectly adequate to protect the off-width if necessary).

Climb the crack system between “Otto Mattock” and Ancient Squamish Secret. As the cracks end trend left and finish at the “Otto Mattock” anchor left of a large block.

Located to the left of Ancient Squamish Secret. Rappel on chains or walk off.
SR, chains on top

The Commonwealth is a popular, new traditional area which offers a very high density of high-quality moderate climbs ranging in length from 15-30m. The approach is short and well developed, protection tends to be plentiful, all anchors are bolted with chains, and the rock has been cleaned immaculately. The crag faces south-east and is heavily shaded, making it very pleasant on hot summer afternoons.

More information and full topos are available at  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
